newsitem.title: USA: Three Starbucks employees shot to death.
newsitem.headline: Three Starbucks employees shot to death.

text.p: Three young Starbucks Corp employees were found shot to death early Monday in a gruesome scene at a Starbucks coffee shop in Washington's luxury Georgetown area, police said.

Two men aged 18 and 25 and a 24-year-old woman, all with at least one gunshot wound to the head, were discovered shortly after 0515 EDT/0915 GMT by a colleague arriving for work. Police shut down busy Wisconsin Avenue, a major traffic artery into downtown Washington and home to exclusive art galleries and upmarket stores, for more than six hours while they investigated the triple homicide.

Sgt. Joe Gentile of the D.C. Metropolitan police said the three victims were employees of Starbucks, a nationwide coffee shop chain. They were later identified as Aaron David Goodrich, 18; Mary Caitrin Mahoney, 24; and Emory Allen Evans, 25, all of whom lived in Northwest Washington.

The coffee cafe had closed at 2000 EDT/2400 GMT Sunday but it was not immediately known when the three died. Police said an employee of Starbucks flagged down a bus driver on Wisconsin Avenue after finding the bodies in a back room of the two-story building. Gentile said there were no suspects or possible motives at this time.
Local television reported that no money appeared to be missing from the store and said all the doors were locked when the employee who discovered the bodies arrived before dawn.
Each of the victims was shot in the head at least once and they most likely were killed shortly after closing on Sunday night, according to WRC-TV.
Starbucks said it was "deeply saddened" by the tragedy and offered to provide whatever assistance necessary to families of the victims.
The murders came a day after Washington's Mayor Marion Barry declared the streets of the nation's capital were the safest in the United States.
